title: Foundation: Apprenticeship and Safety Basics
description: A pass in G.C.E. O/L is a good start. The most common entry is as a helper or apprentice in a welding workshop or a vehicle garage. The initial focus is on safety, learning about tools, and observing skilled professionals.
institutes: Apprenticeship at a local workshop or garage

title: Vocational Training (NVQ Level 3 & 4)
description: Enroll in a formal training program for Welding or as an Auto Mechanic at a vocational institute. This will provide theoretical knowledge and certified practical skills, leading to an NVQ qualification which is highly valued.
qualifications: NVQ Level 4 in Welding or Motor Vehicle Mechanic

title: Skilled Welder / Mechanic
description: Work as a qualified professional. A welder might work in construction, shipbuilding, or manufacturing. A mechanic would work in a garage or service center, diagnosing and repairing vehicles. Practical experience is key to becoming faster and more accurate.

title: Master Technician / Specialist Welder
description: Become an expert in a specific area. A welder could become a certified pipe welder for high-pressure systems or an underwater welder. A mechanic could specialize in hybrid/electric vehicles, automatic transmissions, or a specific car brand.
institutes: N/A - On-the-job specialization and advanced training

title: Workshop Foreman / Own Garage or Workshop
description: Advance to a supervisory role, managing a workshop or a team on a large project. With strong experience and entrepreneurial skills, many master technicians open their own successful garage or welding/fabrication workshop.
